A straight line is drawn on an aeronautical chart and the true track between two positions at different latitudes on that line changes by 28°. What does this mean?

options.text: The chart meridians at the two positions converge with an angle of 28°.
The chart meridians at the two positions converge with an angle of 14°.
The Earth meridians at the two positions converge with an angle of 14°.
The Earth meridians at the two positions converge with an angle of 28°.

Which formula can be used to calculate the climb gradient?

options.text: Gradient in degrees = Arctg (Altitude difference (feet) / ground distance (feet)).
Gradient in degrees = (Altitude difference (ft) × 100) ÷ Ground difference (in ft)

variant.question: Which formula can be used to calculate the climb gradient?

options.text: Gradient in % = altitude difference (feet) × 100 / ground difference (feet)
Gradient in % = altitude difference (feet) × 100 / ground difference (NM)
Gradient in % = altitude difference (feet) × 60 / ground difference (feet)
Gradient in % = Arctg (Altitude difference (feet) / ground distance (feet)).

Which statement about meridians is correct?

options.text: A meridian and its anti-meridian form a complete great circle.
All meridians are parallel to the Greenwich Meridian.
A meridian is a complete great circle of 360°.
The plane of a meridian is parallel to the Equator.

variant.question: Which statement about meridians is correct?

options.text: A meridian and its anti-meridian form a complete great circle.
The plane of a meridian is parallel to the equator.
All meridians are parallel to the Meridian of Greenwich.
A meridian is a complete great circle of 360°.

variant.question: The difference between the initial true track of the great circle on the surface of the Earth joining two positions A and B (of unequal northern latitude and eastern longitude) and the true track of arrival at B is equal to..

options.text: the earth convergency of the meridians at A and B.
half of the conversion angle of the meridians at A and B.
half of the earth convergency of the meridians at A and B.
the conversion angle of the meridians at A and B.

Describe the location of the International Date Line?

options.text: It is partly on and partly in the vicinity of the 180° E/W meridian.
It is exactly on the 180° E/W meridian.
It is east of the 180° E/W meridian.
It is west of the 180° E/W meridian.

variant.question: What is the cause of the continuous variation in the length of the apparent solar day throughout the year?

options.text: The tilt of the Earth’s axis and the elliptical orbit of the Earth around the Sun.
The fact that the Earth is closest to the Sun around the 1st of January.
The fact that the Earth is closest to the Sun around the 1st of July.
